text: The ellipsis is used to slice higher-dimensional data structures.
It's designed to mean at this point, insert as many full slices (:) to extend the multi-dimensional slice to all dimensions.

childList.text: at this point, insert as many full slices (:) to extend the multi-dimensional slice to all dimensions

code:
>>> from numpy import arange
>>> a = arange(16).reshape(2,2,2,2)

text: Now, you have a 4-dimensional matrix of order 2x2x2x2.
To select all first elements in the 4th dimension, you can use the ellipsis notation
In your own implementations, you're free to ignore the contract mentioned above and use it for whatever you see fit.
You'd use it in your own class, since no builtin class makes use of it.
Numpy uses it, as stated in the documentation.
In your own class, you'd use it like this:

code:
>>> class TestEllipsis(object):
...     def __getitem__(self, item):
...         if item is Ellipsis:
...             return "Returning all items"
...         else:
...             return "return %r items" % item
... 
>>> x = TestEllipsis()
>>> print x[2]
return 2 items
>>> print x[...]
Returning all items

text: Of course, there is the python documentation, and language reference.

This is another use for Ellipsis, which has nothing to do with slices: I often use it in intra-thread communication with queues, as a mark that signals "Done"; it's there, it's an object, it's a singleton, and its name means "lack of", and it's not the overused None (which could be put in a queue as part of normal data flow).
